subject: Design
subcategory: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us
title: Thalidomide: The Drug That Changed Product Testing
description: A 60-second lesson on Thalidomide: The Drug That Changed Product Testing.

hook.text: In the late 1950s, a sleeping pill for pregnant women caused 10,000 babies to be born with severe limb deformities.

buildup.text: Thalidomide was marketed as perfectly safe. It hadn't been tested on pregnant animals before release.

discovery.text: The drug crossed the placental barrier and disrupted limb development in the first trimester.

twist.text: The drug had been tested â€” but not on pregnant women. No one checked the most vulnerable users.

climax.text: Thalidomide led to the modern drug approval process â€” rigorous testing, clinical trials, and safety reviews.

punchline.text: Thalidomide proved: test on everyone who'll use it, or don't ship.

quiz.question: What lasting change did the thalidomide disaster create?
options: Rigorous drug approval processes with mandatory clinical trials
